data.title: Rapp Square and Monument to General Rapp, Colmar
meta_keywords: Rapp Square and Monument to General Rapp
data.meta_description: Rapp Square and Monument to General Rapp in Colmar, France - sight map, attraction information, photo and list of walking tours containing this attraction. Get offline map and directions using our GPSmyCity self-guided walking tours app for your mobile device.
data.text:
Place Rapp (Rapp Square) is the main square in the town of Colmar. This public square is located in the Center district. The square owes its name to General Jean Rapp (1773 - 1821), a native of the city. The square was used as a car park until 2000, when it became entirely pedestrian, the car park being buried under place. On this square are remarkable buildings.

The monument to General Rapp is situated in the middle of the square. In 1854 and on the recommendations of Colonel Marnier, Bartholdi, then aged 20, was commissioned to create a statue representing the general of the Empire Jean Rapp (Colmar 1771 - Rheinweiler 1821). The statue was originally displayed on the Champs-Élysées in Paris and displayed at the 1855 Universal Exhibition. It was inaugurated onAugust 31, 1856 in Colmar.

This statue was knocked down by the Germans on August 30, 1940 during the occupation then restored after the liberation, in 1948 (just like the statue of Admiral Bruat located not far away). The architect was called Xavier Hatz.

Sight description based on Wikipedia.

Create Your Own Walk in Colmar

Creating your own self-guided walk in Colmar is easy and fun. Choose the city attractions that you want to see and a walk route map will be created just for you. You can even set your hotel as the start point of the walk.

Colmar Introduction Walking Tour

Charlemagne was well acquainted with Colmar in his wars with the Saxons from 772 to 804 AD. Carolingian emperor Charles the Fat held an assembly there in 884. It was a free imperial city under Emperor Frederick II in 1226. Captured and held by Sweden in 1632, it was conquered at last by Louis XIV of France in 1673.

In 1871 it was annexed by the German Empire as a result of the Franco-Prussian... view more

Tour Duration: 1 Hour(s)

Travel Distance: 1.5 Km or 0.9 Miles
